awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Cranial Base Development in Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address questions about primate and human biology using cutting-edge visualization techniques to map the cellular processes involved in growth and development of cranial cartilage and bone across a wide range of primates.  Findings from this project will advance knowledge about the ways in which cranial growth determines overall skull shape, which is important for understanding primate adaptations and life history through time. The project will support research infrastructure and training of young scientists, and may inform clinical research and treatments for children with cranial malformations.

This study relates differences in cranial base structure (including degree of basicranial flexion and facial orientation) to direct evidence of growth processes. Nine primate species are studied using a novel combination of micro-computed tomography and histological procedures to create 3D virtual reconstructions of the developing skull.  Growth patterns in cranial base synchondroses are quantified using linear and cross-sectional area measurements of cartilaginous zones.  Cranial shape in perinatal and older subadults is described using volumetric, angular, and landmark-based morphometric data.  A combination of descriptive and inferential statistics are applied to address four specific aims: 1) describe the structure of the perinatal cranial base in a comparative sample of primates; 2) document evidence of cellular and tissue-level mechanisms contributing to growth; 3) test for a phylogenetic effect in perinatal cranial base structure; and 4) test the association of cranial base growth patterns with cranial base angle and facial orientation in the perinatal period and in the adult. This project is the first to assess early postnatal synchondroseal patency or fusion in a broad range of primates and advance understanding of growth characteristics of bone and cartilage by directly observing indicators of chondrocyte proliferation and hypertrophy, two drivers of interstitial growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biological variation in the skull is critical to many fields of study, including paleontology, zoology, and clinical studies of human malformations.  Funding for this collaborative research (BCS-1830894 and BCS-1830919) supported work at the University of Florida and Slippery Rock University on developmental mechanisms that produce differences in skull shape across primates.  Results from this research were published in eight peer-reviewed manuscripts, including one recently accepted for publication, and thirty presentations at national and international scientific meetings.  Imaging data produced in this study were made available online to other researchers to build scientific infrastructure and encourage reproducibility.  Grant funds and the data produced in this project supported the professional development of 12 graduate students and five undergraduate students at the University of Florida and Slippery Rock University, many of whom have advanced to faculty positions, clinical practice, or further graduate study. 

The purpose of this research was to show how localized growth processes in the cranial base around the time of birth influence the eventual shape of the skull in adults.  The cranial base is the floor of the braincase.  It is originally formed in cartilage that ossifies to become bone.  The cartilage of the cranial base extends into the face, forming the nasal septum and walls of the nasal cavity.  Growth processes in this cartilage result in integration of the braincase and facial skeleton.  This project used a diverse sample of primates to capture a broad range of craniofacial variation, including long- and short-snouted primates.  All animals were ethically obtained following natural deaths.  CT (computed tomography) imaging was used to create 3D virtual models of newborn skulls, and histological analysis allowed study of cellular and tissue-level mechanisms contributing to growth. Multivariate statistics and advanced morphometric techniques were used to quantify the shape of the skull and test 1) the correlation with cellular characteristics observed in the newborn cranial base and 2) the difference among major groups of primates with distinct evolutionary histories (e.g., strepsirrhines vs. anthropoids).

Results of the study provided novel information about the potential for growth at midline synchondroses (cartilaginous growth centers) in the cranial base of all primates. The investigators documented, for the first time, that a diverse array of primates are similar to humans in possessing ?open? (i.e., unfused) synchondroses at birth, and these synchondroses grow most rapidly prenatally, at birth, and throughout early infancy (see Figure 1). This similarity means that nonhuman primates can serve as valid models for understanding human cranial base growth. However, there are certain differences in many nonhuman primates compared to humans. For example, synchondroses in the center and anterior end of the sphenoid bone continue growing for a longer time in most nonhuman primates than reported for humans. This may account, in part, for the great degree of shortening observed in the human face.

Products of this research included 3D virtual models of developing bone and cartilage in newborn primates.  These visualizations provided support for the role of cartilage as a factor influencing both braincase and facial skeleton.  For example, earlier degeneration of cartilage in some anthropoid primates compared to strepsirrhine primates was associated with shorter snouts observed in the adults of that group (see Figure 2). Funding for this project also supported advances in knowledge on the use of iodine enhanced CT scans to visualize nasal cavities as well as the mucosa that surrounds it.  Bats and dogs were included as a parallel to primates, because they also display a great amount of variation in snout lengths. Finally, in one species of primate, the entire skeleton was studied from birth to adolescent ages. This yield a ?growth atlas? of cranial and limb bones, tracking the ossification of parts of bones across age. This has been used as an instructional tool in a class taught by one of the investigators, to illustrate bone maturation for physical therapy graduate students.   

Results from this project on growth patterns in the primate cranial base provide novel information on which future studies will build.  In addition to advancing knowledge in biological anthropology, these results are broadly relevant for any study addressing cranial variation, impacting research in paleontology, evolutionary biology, comparative anatomy, and clinical studies of human dysmorphology.
